title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; A Club Dies; So Does Part Of Brooklyn

body: HEY, gang! Guess what kind of adult entertainment is hot -- and legal -- in New York these days. Give up? It's puppetry. Gaining more respect as an art form, puppetry seems to promise wider audiences, higher esteem and perhaps bigger money for a tight-knit group of city artists. title: Make Way For Grown-Ups

body: FRAZER-William L. Died on January 19, 1999 at home after a long bout with lung disease. Born in Brooklyn on March 11, 1917 to Charles and Lela Frazer, Mr. Frazer grew up in Brooklyn Heights. After graduating from Pratt Institute in 1938, he went on to a very successful career as an artist, photographer and advertising art director, recently retired
title: Paid Notice: Deaths FRAZER, WILLIAM L.

body: Bennett Harrison, a leading radical economist, vocal critic of United States economic policy and the co-author of the 1983 book ''The De-Industrialization of America,'' died at home on Sunday of complications from cancer of the esophagus. He was 56 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights. Professor Harrison was professor of urban political economy
title: Bennett Harrison, 56, Urban Economist, Dies

body: When the Board of Education divvied up the $10.9 billion it plans to spend on construction, repair and renovation in the next five years, it allotted some districts hundreds of millions of dollars to build schools. author: Stefani Jackenthal is a professional adventure racer competing in multisport racing.
body: The double jab set up a right-cross, left-hook combination that landed firmly on the bridge on my nose with an audible crack. We were only 30 seconds into the first of two three-minute rounds. My eyes burned; my previously unblemished nose throbbed. Which, I suppose, was only natural since I was being pummeled by the 119-pound female Golden Gloves
title: Weekend Warrior; Following Her Bliss Into a Blast of Jabs, Hooks and Crosses
